messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Re: Deus Destroyed
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks you Mr Eckman. I will try to get this book, seems that it could be a great support to my research. Until now I had been doing cross references between
messages.messageBody:
Thanks you Mr Eckman.
I will try to get this book, seems that it could be a
great support to my research. Until now I had been
doing cross references between the History of the
Catholic Church and the History of Japan. This fact
had made that my research turn to become a synthesis
effort of two different kind of sources. But it seems
a good approach to my tutor professors (research
project) anyway.
Thanks again.

"The Light shines in Darkness, and Darkness cannot
overcome it"

--- James Eckman <ronin_engineer@...> wrote:

> Try abebooks.com, $48 is still not cheap but if it's
> what your looking
> for.... Alibris has one for $49. One of the local
> university libraries
> has it for free. A good researcher has to work the
> book hunt pretty hard
> for the fun stuff. Lots easier though than when you
> actually had to call
> libraries to find out if they had a book or where
> you could find a copy!
> I have no nostalgia for card catalogs either having
> had to maintain one.
> For Mark, you can get it from the San Jose Library
> or through Link+ if
> you want to read it.
>
> Jim Eckman
>
>

>

messages.subject: Re: Deus Destroyed
messages.msgSnippet: Try abebooks.com, $48 is still not cheap but if it s what your looking for.... Alibris has one for $49. One of the local university libraries has it for free.
messages.messageBody:
Try abebooks.com, $48 is still not cheap but if it's what your looking
for.... Alibris has one for $49. One of the local university libraries
has it for free. A good researcher has to work the book hunt pretty hard
for the fun stuff. Lots easier though than when you actually had to call
libraries to find out if they had a book or where you could find a copy!
I have no nostalgia for card catalogs either having had to maintain one.
For Mark, you can get it from the San Jose Library or through Link+ if
you want to read it.

Jim Eckman
